prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Map CO(2-1) emission in outflow in IRAS17208-0014
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We aim to map the CO(2-1) emission in IRAS 17208-0014 at a resolution of ~0.35 arcsec, and recover all flux at scales up to 6 arcsec.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
GENERAL SAMPLE: Our sensitivity estimates are set by the estimated amount of cold molecular gas in the outflows. We detect masses of warm molecular H2 gas in the outflows ranging from 4500 - 6500 Msun. Conversion cold to warm molecular gas mass is in range 10^5 - 10^7 (Dale et al 2005). Taking conservative estimate of 10^5 [which is possibly an order of magnitude too low, but may compensate for potential gas heating in the outflow region], we predict to find cold molecular gas masses of 4.5 - 6.5 x 10^8 Msun in the outflows. This is in agreement with cold molecular gas outflows in starburst galaxies and QSOs by Cicone et al (2013). Taking the standard formula for L'CO and a conservative ratio of L'CO(2-1)/L'CO(1-0) = 0.8 (for sub-thermally excited gas) we predict integrated CO(2-1) intensities of 5.5 - 7.0 Jy km/s (again in agreement with CO(1-0) obervations by Cicone et al 2013). The FWHM of the velocity dispersion of the outflowing H2 ranges from 150 - 300 km/s (with outflow velocities 250 - 400 km/s). Therefore, minimum expected integrated CO(2-1) peak flux is about 25 - 35 mJy. The exact values per object are given in Fig.2. We stress that this is a conservative estimate, as the typical conversion factor cold-to-warm molecular gas for ULIRGs may be an order of magnitude higher. In order to spatially and kinematically resolve the outflow, our aim is per object to detect this peak flux at a 10 sigma level per 0.35'' x 0.35'' beam across an 80 km/s channel. This involves delution factors of (Area outflow)/(ALMA cylce-2 beam) = 13 - 40 for our objects, resulting in CO(2-1) peak flux densities of 1.5 - 2.3 mJy/beam, and thus requested 5 sigma sensitivities of 0.15 - 0.23 mJy/beam per 80 km/s channel. This takes on average less than 1.5h per object (including overhead), or 5.5h in total for this project. Our galaxies are small (< 6'') and the gas is kinematically resolved at scales < 4-6'' per channel (Fig.2). We therefore prefer observations in C34-5 array, which can provide ~0.35'' resolution and LAS = 6''.
TARGET SPECIFIC: IRAS 17208-0014 has a predicted integrated peak flux of > 96 mJy. The outflow is spread across ~5.0 arcsec^2, or ~41 ALMA beams. This results in an expected CO(2-1) peak flux per ALMA beam of 2.3 mJy/beam. To detect this at a 10 sigma level across a 80 km/s channel, we require an rms noise level of 0.23 mJy/beam. This requires 1.37h of observing time (including overheads).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Map CO(2-1) emission in outflow in IRAS 12112+0305
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We aim to map the CO(2-1) emission in IRAS 12112+-305 at a resolution of ~0.35 arcsec, and recover all flux at scales up to 6 arcsec.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
GENERAL SAMPLE: Our sensitivity estimates are set by the estimated amount of cold molecular gas in the outflows. We detect masses of warm molecular H2 gas in the outflows ranging from 4500 - 6500 Msun. Conversion cold to warm molecular gas mass is in range 10^5 - 10^7 (Dale et al 2005). Taking conservative estimate of 10^5 [which is possibly an order of magnitude to low, but may compensate for potential gas heating in the outflow region], we predict to find cold molecular gas masses of 4.5 - 6.5 x 10^8 Msun in the outflows. This is in agreement with cold molecular gas outflows in starburst galaxies and QSOs by Cicone et al (2013). Taking the standard formula for L'CO and a conservative ratio of L'CO(2-1)/L'CO(1-0) = 0.8 (for sub-thermally excited gas) we predict integrated CO(2-1) intensities of 5.5 - 7.0 Jy km/s (again in agreement with CO(1-0) obervations by Cicone et al 2013). The FWHM of the velocity dispersion of the outflowing H2 ranges from 150 - 300 km/s (with outflow velocities 250 - 400 km/s). Therefore, minimum expected integrated CO(2-1) peak flux is about 25 - 35 mJy. The exact values per object are given in Fig.2. We stress that this is a conservative estimate, as the typical conversion factor cold-to-warm molecular gas for ULIRGs may be an order of magnitude higher. In order to spatially and kinematically resolve the outflow, our aim is per object to detect this peak flux at a 10 sigma level per 0.35'' x 0.35'' beam across an 80 km/s channel. This involves delution factors of (Area outflow)/(ALMA cylce-2 beam) = 13 - 40 for our objects, resulting in CO(2-1) peak flux densities of 1.5 - 2.3 mJy/beam, and thus requested 10 sigma sensitivities of 0.15 - 0.23 mJy/beam per 20 km/s channel. This takes on average less than 1.5h per object (including overhead), or 5.5h in total for this project. Our galaxies are small (< 6'') and the gas is kinematically resolved at scales < 4-6'' per channel (Fig.2). We therefore prefer observations in C34-5 array, which can provide ~0.35'' resolution and LAS = 6''.
TARGET SPECIFIC: IRAS 12112+0305 has a predicted integrated peak flux of > 35 mJy. The outflow is spread across ~2 arcsec^2, or 17 ALMA beams. This results in an expected CO(2-1) peak flux per ALMA beam of 2.0 mJy/beam. To detect this at a 10 sigma level across a 80 km/s channel, we require an rms noise level of 0.2 mJy/beam. This requires 2.13h of observing time (including overheads).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Map CO(2-1) emission in outflow in IRAS 14348-1447
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We aim to map the CO(2-1) emission in IRAS 14348-1447 at a resolution of ~0.35 arcsec, and recover all flux at scales up to 6 arcsec.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
GENERAL SAMPLE: Our sensitivity estimates are set by the estimated amount of cold molecular gas in the outflows. We detect masses of warm molecular H2 gas in the outflows ranging from 4500 - 6500 Msun. Conversion cold to warm molecular gas mass is in range 10^5 - 10^7 (Dale et al 2005). Taking conservative estimate of 10^5 [which is possibly an order of magnitude to low, but may compensate for potential gas heating in the outflow region], we predict to find cold molecular gas masses of 4.5 - 6.5 x 10^8 Msun in the outflows. This is in agreement with cold molecular gas outflows in starburst galaxies and QSOs by Cicone et al (2013). Taking the standard formula for L'CO and a conservative ratio of L'CO(2-1)/L'CO(1-0) = 0.8 (for sub-thermally excited gas) we predict integrated CO(2-1) intensities of 5.5 - 7.0 Jy km/s (again in agreement with CO(1-0) obervations by Cicone et al 2013). The FWHM of the velocity dispersion of the outflowing H2 ranges from 150 - 300 km/s (with outflow velocities 250 - 400 km/s). Therefore, minimum expected integrated CO(2-1) peak flux is about 25 - 35 mJy. The exact values per object are given in Fig.2. We stress that this is a conservative estimate, as the typical conversion factor cold-to-warm molecular gas for ULIRGs may be an order of magnitude higher. In order to spatially and kinematically resolve the outflow, our aim is per object to detect this peak flux at a 10 sigma level per 0.35'' x 0.35'' beam across an 80 km/s channel. This involves delution factors of (Area outflow)/(ALMA cylce-2 beam) = 13 - 40 for our objects, resulting in CO(2-1) peak flux densities of 1.5 - 2.3 mJy/beam, and thus requested 10 sigma sensitivities of 0.15 - 0.23 mJy/beam per 20 km/s channel. This takes on average less than 1.5h per object (including overhead), or 5.5h in total for this project. Our galaxies are small (< 6'') and the gas is kinematically resolved at scales < 4-6'' per channel (Fig.2). We therefore prefer observations in C34-5 array, which can provide ~0.35'' resolution and LAS = 6''.
TARGET SPECIFIC: IRAS 14348-1447 has a predicted integrated peak flux of > 24 mJy. The outflow is spread across ~2 arcsec^2, or 16 ALMA beams. This results in an expected CO(2-1) peak flux per ALMA beam of 1.5 mJy/beam. The velocity dispersion of the gas is 1.5x that of the other two objects. herefore, we aim to detect this at a 10 sigma level across a 120 km/s channel, thus require an rms noise level of 0.15 mJy/beam. This requires 2.19h of observing time (including overheads).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Models predict that massive gas outflows (negative feedback) associated with nuclear starbursts could control the growth of black-holes and self-regulate star formation in galaxies. Using near-IR/optical Integral-Field Spectroscopy, we characterised such massive gas outflows across a range of gas phases (coronal, ionised and warm molecular) in the centres of nearby Ultra Luminous Infra-Red Galaxies. We accurately mapped massive (4500 - 6500 Msun) and extended (2-3 kpc) outflows of warm molecular H2 gas, de-coupled from the main galaxy discs. Based on these massive warm H2 outflows, we predict to find outflow rates of cold molecular gas of ~150-1500 M(sun)/yr. We here propose sub-arcsec CO(2-1) observations of three of these ULIRGs, which cover a range in morphologies and types of nuclear activity. The aim is to map the cold molecular gas in the outflows and -together with the other gas phases- derive important outflow parameters like the mass outflow rates and mass loading factors (which will establish whether star formation is being quenched). With this, we will obtain a 3D, multi-phase view of the ISM in three of the most actively starforming galaxies in the nearby Universe.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:keyword: Luminous and Ultra-Luminous Infra-Red Galaxies (LIRG & ULIRG)

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Observatorio de Madrid, Observatorio Astronómico Nacional
Astrophysics Department, Instituto de Fisica de Cantabria CSIC/UC
Earth and Space Sciences, Chalmers University of Technology
Onsala Space Observatory, Chalmers University of Technology
